(FILES) The building of the Washington Post newspaper headquarter is seen on K Street in Washington DC on May 16, 2019. The Washington Post, a flagship American newspaper owned by billionaire Jeff Bezos, instituted major cuts to its newsroom staff on February 4, 2026. Most foreign correspondent positions are being eliminated, one of them told AFP, and media reports said that hundreds of journalists are impacted. (Photo by Eric BARADAT / AFP) 

 International News, Latest News 

February 5, 2026




 ‚ÄòSave the Post‚Äô: Hundreds protest cuts at famed US newspaper 







WASHINGTON, United States (AFP) ‚Äî Several hundred people rallied outside The Washington Post headquarters on Thursday to protest its decision to lay off hundreds of journalists, including most of its overseas staff.

‚ÄúDemocracy dies in darkness. And you, Jeff Bezos, have turned off the lights,‚Äù a sign at the demonstration read, referring to the newspaper‚Äôs front-page slogan and its billionaire owner, who has become close to US President Donald Trump during the Republican‚Äôs second term.

The sweeping cuts at the Post announced on Wednesday came as major traditional media outlets in the United States face intense pressure from Trump, who routinely denigrates journalists as ‚Äúfake news‚Äù and has launched multiple lawsuits against media organisations.

READ: Washington Post announces ‚Äòpainful‚Äô job cuts

‚ÄúIn a time where we‚Äôve seen unprecedented attacks on the press, and anti- or negative sentiment toward journalists for just doing their jobs, it‚Äôs dangerous to cut staff this way,‚Äù said Michael Brice-Saddler, who covered the US capital for the Post and has now been laid off.

‚ÄúThese cuts are not the fault of our staff, yet they are the ones who bear the brunt of the cost. They lose resources, they lose the ability to tell stories that are meaningful to Washington,‚Äù Brice-Saddler said.

The Post did not disclose the number of jobs being eliminated, but The New York Times reported that approximately 300 of its 800 journalists were laid off.

Most of the paper‚Äôs journalists overseas were let go, including its entire Middle East roster and its Kyiv-based Ukraine correspondent, as the war with Russia grinds on.

Sports, graphics and local news departments were sharply scaled back, and the paper‚Äôs daily podcast, Post Reports, was suspended, local media reported.

Bezos reined in the newspaper‚Äôs liberal-leaning editorial page and blocked an endorsement of Democratic candidate Kamala Harris days before the 2024 election ‚Äî breaking the so-called firewall of editorial independence. He was widely seen as bowing to Trump.

The Wall Street Journal reported last month that 250,000 digital subscribers left the Post after it refrained from endorsing Harris, and the paper lost around $100 million in 2024 as advertising and subscription revenues fell.

Marissa J Lang, an enterprise reporter who was fired by the Post, said the full effect of the layoffs remains to be seen.

‚ÄúA lot of people have been asking me about the impact of these cuts, and I have very honestly been telling them, I don‚Äôt think we know yet,‚Äù Lang said.

‚ÄúThe impact of losing 300 journalists who hold power to account, who investigate corruption, who tell you about what‚Äôs happening in war zones overseas, and whether your kids‚Äô schools will be open because it snowed, is immeasurable,‚Äù Lang said.

news.title: Harris Copies Newsom, Launches 'Headquarters' Account
news.text:
The former vice president and 2024 Democratic presidential nominee on Thursday rebooted the KamalaHQ account, which has over 1 million followers on X and more than 5 million on TikTok, as just Headquarters, which in a partnership with the left-leaning People for the American Way she‚Äôs calling ‚Äúan online organizing project for next generation campaigning.‚Äù‚ÄúConservatives build permanent organizing infrastructure. Progressives have historically built machines that dismantle after Election Day. Headquarters is the end of that cycle,‚Äù reads a press release from the new group, which also now plans to post on Substack, YouTube and other platforms...Harris will have an honorary role in Headquarters as chair emerita, with a group of advisers and operatives drawn from both her campaign alumni and People for the American Way, including her top senior adviser Kirsten Allen and Rob Flaherty, who served as deputy campaign manager for Joe Biden and then Harris in 2024. Parker Butler and Lauren Kapp, who led the KamalaHQ team in 2024, will remain involved.

Here's her pitch for the new account.

Welcome to Headquarters, the new Gen-Z led progressive content hub. pic.twitter.com/7EQyz3DFpd‚Äî HQ (@headquarters_67) February 5, 2026

Well, she didn't break into a cackle so that's a win for her I guess. But the account itself is just more of the same junk.

Donald Trump when he sees a teenage Miss Universe contestant üëá https://t.co/RSOgRU1VkG‚Äî HQ (@headquarters_67) February 5, 2026

The GOP gave it a thumbs up, probably because they expect it to be very cringe.

üëç https://t.co/COCDgziQeP‚Äî GOP (@GOP) February 5, 2026

And they are not wrong. They are really going to be big with the 14 year-old voters.

Wait, she actually put ‚Äú67‚Äù in the handle to try to appeal to the youths?This is why she‚Äôs the GOAT. No other politician comes close to this level of cringe. pic.twitter.com/pBk8hIHKVV‚Äî Bonchie (@bonchieredstate) February 5, 2026

Is she winning yet? And, hey, what is she wearing? Is this a message about her appeal to swing states?

Announcement so dumb I almost missed that she is dressed like the Joker https://t.co/oJ5fvK410F‚Äî Kenjac (@JackKennedy) February 5, 2026

It's really just the Newsom account under a different name.

So I guess Kamala's major new project is just a shitposting account. pic.twitter.com/TXtaxhtlMH‚Äî Chuck Ross (@ChuckRossDC) February 5, 2026

Really, she's had a year to come up with something and what she came up with is a knock-off of Gavin Newsom's thing. This is no way to head into Brat Summer 2.

my 2yo daughter ran up to me this morning with tears in her eyes. she took a deep breath and said ‚Äúdaddy the world is crumbling and we need a gen-z led progressive content hub to fix it‚Äù and i showed her this. she burst into tears and said ‚Äúwe‚Äôre gonna be ok. this is for RBG‚Äù ‚ù§Ô∏è https://t.co/vDayvJNyQk‚Äî chase (@cfree94) February 5, 2026

Yeah, I'm sure this is going to be great news for someone, probably the Republican party.

This is what not learning a lesson looks like. https://t.co/epw1G2q49T‚Äî Berniegirl No More (@Hedgesgurl) February 5, 2026

Honestly, I think the new account could turn out to be more popular than the Harris campaign. Democrats seem to have an endless appetite for anti-Turmp snark, they just don't have much of an appetite for Kamala Harris. We proved that in the last campaign and, really, nothing has changed. She's the same off-putting disaster of a candidate she was 18 months ago. My prediction: Eventually this site will wind up promoting Gavin Newsom.
news.author: John Sexton

news.title: Inside Harris‚Äôs Plan to Turn Kamala HQ Into a Year-Round Gen Z Hub
news.text: In just over 100 days, Kamala Harris's digital team built something Democrats rarely accomplish: a social media operation that outperformed Donald Trump. Messages of hope, joy, and momentum resonated across TikTok, Instagram, X, and Facebook. By election day, they had amassed 8 million followers‚Äîan unprecedented digital footprint for a campaign run on an accelerated timeline. Then they lost. The digital team that had built this machine sat in silence, watching millions of followers stare at dormant accounts. ‚ÄúComing off November 2024, these accounts were sitting dormant with around 8 million followers collectively,‚Äú Lauren Kapp, who ran the TikTok account during the campaign, told Newsweek. ‚ÄúThe question on everyone's minds was: what is going to happen to these accounts?‚Äú This week, they got their answer: rather than dismantle the operation, Kamala Harris is officially relaunching the campaign accounts as ‚ÄúHeadquarters,‚Äú a permanent digital organizing project designed to operate year-round. The accounts will serve as what the team calls a ‚ÄúGen Z‚Äìled progressive content hub,‚Äú covering political news and fact-checking claims, as they try to compete with the meme-fueled strategy the White House has successfully used. Supporters react as Democratic presidential nominee, U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris concedes the election during a speech at Howard University on November 06, 2024, in Washington, D.C. (Photo by Andrew Harnik/Getty Images) ‚ÄúThis is way bigger than any one election cycle or any one candidate,‚Äù said Arlie Shugar, the video lead on the original Kamala HQ team and director of platforms at People for the American Way, a progressive advocacy organization. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre looking forward to covering the news day in and day out and uplifting progressive voices.‚Äù A Problem Democrats Keep Solving Poorly The decision to keep the accounts alive represents an unusual move in Democratic politics. Historically, campaign digital operations dissolve after Election Day, infrastructure dismantled and teams scattered. The Kamala HQ accounts‚Äîwhich had generated more impressions than both @realDonaldTrump and @TeamTrump combined during the 2024 race‚Äîcould have followed the same path. Instead, Harris's team is treating digital organizing as a permanent problem requiring permanent solutions. ‚ÄúOne of my largest takeaways from 2024 was the fact that Democrats have really been struggling with meeting this moment and the attention economy of the current day and age of digital,‚Äú Kapp, who is managing partner at Luminary Strategies, said. The relaunch of Headquarters, in her view, is a direct response to that recurring failure. Headquarters operates through a three-way partnership: Harris's own team, People for the American Way (where Harris will officially serve on the board), and Luminary Strategies, Kapp's firm. The project currently has 12 staff members and is actively hiring platform-specific strategists and video editors. ‚ÄúOur goal is basically to build back the team in the same way that it was built in 2024,‚Äú Kapp explained. ‚ÄúSo to have Twitter strategists, Facebook strategists, Instagram strategists, TikTok strategists.‚Äú The Broader Stakes The relaunch comes as Democrats prepare for the 2026 midterm elections and grapple with losing ground among younger voters. Trump won 43 percent of voters ages 18-24 in 2024, up from 31 percent in 2020, according to CNN exit polling. Recent polling suggests Gen Z sentiment toward Trump has deteriorated since his return to office, creating an opening Democrats hope to exploit. Harris has not declared plans to run for president in 2028, but the decision to build permanent infrastructure raises inevitable questions about her political future. When asked whether Headquarters signals such intentions, both women deflected. Supporters cheer as US Vice President and Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris speaks during a Get Out the Vote rally at the Pennsylvania Farm Show Complex & Expo Center in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, on October 30, 2024. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP) ‚ÄúThis specifically just shows the Vice President's commitment to Gen. Z,‚Äú Kapp said. ‚ÄúThis really is an investment into Gen. Z and people who are trying to reach young people. But this account is more than any one candidate or campaign.‚Äú For Harris's team, the stakes are clear. ‚ÄúAfter all of the headlines about how we lost the election online in 2024 and we didn't go on enough podcasts, and we didn't do this, and we didn't do that, this is her taking a direct action to try to solve for that,‚Äú Kapp said. ‚ÄúAnd while it's not going to solve everything, this is a huge step forward in the right direction.‚Äú However, the project faces real challenges. The team attempted to secure the @headquarters handle on X but was unsuccessful. According to a source familiar with the matter, the platform requested a significant sum for the handle, making the acquisition unfeasible. Also, maintaining engagement during non-election years is typically harder than during campaigns. Content that went viral under the banner of a presidential race may struggle without that same galvanizing moment. Some Democratic strategists have also questioned whether another Gen-Z-focused organization makes sense when other groups already compete for similar funding and audiences.
news.summary: After 2024, the Kamala HQ digital team tells Newsweek why their Gen Z strategy isn‚Äôt shutting down.
news.author: Jesus Mesa,Leonardo Feldman

(FILES) The building of the Washington Post newspaper headquarter is seen on K Street in Washington DC on May 16, 2019. The Washington Post, a flagship American newspaper owned by billionaire Jeff Bezos, instituted major cuts to its newsroom staff on February 4, 2026. Most foreign correspondent positions are being eliminated, one of them told AFP, and media reports said that hundreds of journalists are impacted. (Photo by Eric BARADAT / AFP) 

 International News, Latest News, News 

February 5, 2026




 Washington Post announces ‚Äòpainful‚Äô job cuts 







WASHINGTON, United States (AFP) ‚ÄîThe Washington Post, owned by billionaire Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, announced major job cuts Wednesday, saying that ‚Äúpainful‚Äù restructuring was needed at the storied newspaper.

The Post, which gained legendary status when its reporting helped bring down president Richard Nixon in the Watergate scandal, will see ‚Äúsubstantial‚Äù reductions in its newsroom, Executive Editor Matt Murray said.

The shrinking of the Post comes as major traditional media outlets in the United States face intense pressure from President Donald Trump, who routinely denigrates journalists as ‚Äúfake news‚Äù and has launched multiple lawsuits over coverage of his presidency.

Bezos, one of the world‚Äôs richest people, has become close to Trump in the Republican‚Äôs second term. His Amazon behemoth controversially paid Trump‚Äôs wife, First Lady Melania Trump, a reported $40 million for a documentary this year, along with another $35 million for marketing.

Murray said the shifts at the Post reflect the radically changing economy for news media.

This ‚Äúwill help to secure our future‚Ä¶and provide us stability moving forward,‚Äù Murray said in a note to employees.

He cited changes to the news ecosystem, from individuals who ‚Äúgenerate impact at low cost‚Äù to AI-generated content, as well as financial challenges that have already produced rounds of cost-cutting and buyouts at the Post.

‚ÄúThe company‚Äôs structure is too rooted in a different era, when we were a dominant, local print product,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd even as we produce much excellent work, we too often wrote from one perspective, for one slice of the audience.‚Äù

On Facebook, Marty Baron, the Post‚Äôs executive editor until 2021, said: ‚ÄúThis ranks among the darkest days in the history of one of the world‚Äôs greatest news organizations.‚Äù

‚Äì War zone layoff ‚Äì

The Post did not disclose the number of job cuts, but the New York Times reports approximately 300 of its 800 journalists were laid off.

Most of the paper‚Äôs journalists overseas were let go, includings its entire Middle East roster and its Kyiv-based Ukraine correspondent.

Sports, graphics and local news departments were sharply scaled back and the paper‚Äôs daily podcast, Post Reports, was suspended, local media reported.

Murray said the Post would now focus on politics, national security, technology, investigations, and business, among other topics.

But a reporter who covered Amazon ‚Äî currently valued at $2.6 trillion ‚Äî was let go.

‚ÄúThese layoffs are not inevitable. A newsroom cannot be hollowed out without consequences for its credibility, its reach and its future,‚Äù the labor union representing many Post journalists said in a statement.

It called for supporters of the paper, acquired by Bezos in 2013, to rally outside its Washington headquarters at noon on Thursday.

The White House‚Äôs communications director, Stephen Cheung, issued a typically scornful message.

‚ÄúJust a reminder that printing fake news is not a profitable business model,‚Äù he posted on X.

‚Äì Financial struggles ‚Äì

Baron, the Post‚Äôs former executive editor, said that Post owner Bezos had resisted ‚Äúbrutal pressure‚Äù from Trump in the past, but it was battered by ‚Äúill-conceived decisions that came from the very top.‚Äù

Bezos reined in a liberal-leaning editorial page and blocked an endorsement of Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris days before the 2024 election ‚Äî breaking the so-called firewall of editorial independence, and seen as bowing the knee to Trump.

In response, loyal readers ‚Äúfled the Post. In truth, they were driven away,‚Äù Baron said.

The Wall Street Journal reported last month that 250,000 digital subscribers left the Post after it refrained from endorsing Harris and the paper lost around $100 million in 2024 as advertising and subscription revenues fell.

In May 2024, Post publisher Will Lewis told staffers the paper lost $77 million over the preceding year and lost half of its audience since 2020.

In stark contrast, The New York Times announced Wednesday that it gained more than one million digital subscribers in 2025, bringing its total to nearly 13 million and confirming its dominant position in the US media market.

news.title: ‚ÄòSave the Post‚Äô: Hundreds in Washington protest cuts at famed US newspaper
news.text:
WASHINGTON - Several hundred people rallied outside The Washington Post headquarters Feb 5 to protest its decision to lay off hundreds of journalists, including most of its overseas staff.

‚ÄúDemocracy dies in darkness. And you, Jeff Bezos, have turned off the lights,‚Äù a sign at the demonstration read, referring to the newspaper‚Äôs front-page slogan and its billionaire owner, who has become close to President Donald Trump during the Republican‚Äôs second term.

‚ÄúIn a time where we‚Äôve seen unprecedented attacks on the press, and anti- or negative sentiment towards journalists for just doing their jobs, it‚Äôs dangerous to cut staff this way,‚Äù said Mr Michael Brice-Saddler, who covered the US capital for the Post and has now been laid off.

‚ÄúThese cuts are not the fault of our staff, yet they are the ones who bear the brunt of the cost. They lose resources, they lose the ability to tell stories that are meaningful to Washington,‚Äù Mr Brice-Saddler said.

The Post did not disclose the number of jobs being eliminated, but The New York Times reported approximately 300 of its 800 journalists were laid off.

Most of the paper‚Äôs journalists overseas were let go, including its entire Middle East roster and its Kyiv-based Ukraine correspondent as Russia‚Äôs invasion of its neighbour grinds on. 

Sports, graphics and local news departments were sharply scaled back and the paper‚Äôs daily podcast, Post Reports, was suspended, local media reported.

Mr Bezos reined in the newspaper‚Äôs liberal-leaning editorial page and blocked an endorsement of Democratic candidate Kamala Harris days before the 2024 election ‚Äì breaking the so-called firewall of editorial independence. He was widely seen as bowing to Mr Trump. 

The Wall Street Journal reported in January that 250,000 digital subscribers left the Post after it refrained from endorsing Ms Harris and the paper lost around US$100 million (S$127 million) in 2024 as advertising and subscription revenues fell. 

Ms Marissa J. Lang, an enterprise reporter who was fired by the Post, said the full effect of the layoffs remains to be seen.

‚ÄúA lot of people have been asking me about the impact of these cuts, and I have very honestly been telling them, I don‚Äôt think we know yet,‚Äù Ms Lang said.

‚ÄúThe impact of losing 300 journalists who hold power to account, who investigate corruption, who tell you about what‚Äôs happening in war zones overseas, and whether your kids‚Äô schools will be open because it snowed, is immeasurable,‚Äù Ms Lang said. AFP

news.title: Harris relaunch of ‚ÄòKamala HQ‚Äô as Gen Z content hub stokes speculation on what‚Äôs next
news.text:
‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt say this is proof she‚Äôs formally running again, but it‚Äôs clearly a signal of interest,‚Äù Ashleigh Ewald, who served as a Gen Z content creator for Harris‚Äôs 2024 Georgia office, told the Washington Examiner. ‚ÄúVice presidents who are done don‚Äôt usually rebuild digital infrastructure or re-activate former campaign teams. This feels more like keeping the door open than closing it.‚Äù

On Wednesday night, teasers hinted at the return of her social media presence, which officially relaunched Thursday on X and TikTok under the new brand ‚ÄúHeadquarters.‚Äù This rebrand, created with the progressive nonprofit organization People For the American Way, is described as both a ‚Äúyouth mobilization organization‚Äù and a ‚Äúnext-generation campaigning‚Äù initiative.

The ‚Äúheadquarters_67‚Äù account already has five million followers on TikTok and 1.1 million on X. It‚Äôs unclear if the 67 is a reference to the viral internet meme that has been driving parents and teachers crazy for the best part of the past two years. The bio on the X account simply said ‚ÄúElon [Musk] wouldn‚Äôt give us @headquarters.‚Äù

Introducing itself as a ‚ÄúGen-Z led progressive content hub,‚Äù the account features a stylized banner with an inverted bald eagle, an American flag backdrop, and a light green ‚ÄúHeadquarters‚Äù logo subtitled ‚ÄúA News Co.‚Äù

Ewald noted that the rebrand itself is what stands out most.

‚ÄúShifting from KamalaHQ to a broader ‚ÄòHeadquarters‚Äô suggests she‚Äôs thinking beyond a single campaign,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúMore about staying engaged, especially with Gen Z. Harris has long understood that younger voters aren‚Äôt just a future constituency, they‚Äôre an expanding one, and that engagement has to be a two-way conversation, not just messaging at them. At a moment when Democrats are still trying to catch up to Republicans online, this also reads as a practical move. Even if a 2028 run is still down the line, maintaining visibility, relationships, and digital momentum makes sense. It‚Äôs a sign she‚Äôs still very much in the political arena, not stepping away from it.‚Äù

Harris‚Äô social media rebrand aligns with broader Democratic hopes to engage young voters ahead of November‚Äôs midterm elections. While young voters generally favor Democrats, President Donald Trump made notable gains with this group in the 2024 election, winning 43% of voters aged 18-24, up from 31% in 2020.

‚ÄúHeadquarters‚Äù aims to mobilize young people who are pro-fairness and pro-democracy against right-wing extremism. Harris, who ran an unsuccessful last-minute campaign against Trump in 2024, now serves as the organization‚Äôs chair emerita.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs where you can go online to get basically the latest of what‚Äôs going on and also to meet and revisit with some of our great, courageous leaders,‚Äù Harris said in a short launch video. ‚ÄúSo stay engaged, and I‚Äôll see you out there.‚Äù

MY NIGHT WITH KAMALA: HARRIS‚ÄôS ‚ÄòI TOLD YOU SO‚Äô TOUR COMES TO RICHMOND

Headquarters already seems to mirror elements of California Gov. Gavin Newsom‚Äôs popular X account, Governor Newsom Press Office, which blends rapid-fire political messaging with news-style content and often targets and mocks Trump and his administration. One of its first posts features a video of Trump at the National Prayer Breakfast, where he discusses whether he will make it to heaven.

‚ÄúI really think I probably should make it,‚Äù Trump said.

The Headquarters post added a snarky, ‚ÄúMentioned 38,000 times in the Epstein files, btw.‚Äù

Like Newsom, Harris is reportedly considering a 2028 White House run. A new Harvard-Harris poll released this week shows her leading the Democratic contenders, while Vice President JD Vance holds a commanding lead among Republicans. With her new social media operation and a national book tour underway, Harris appears to be strongly hinting at a possible return to the White House stage.

WHY YOU SHOULD NOT BET AGAINST KAMALA HARRIS 2028 ON PREDICTION MARKETS 

Shroff Kaivan, a political commentator and 2025 Democratic National Committee delegate who supported Harris, said the buzz around the rebranded social media sites shows America‚Äôs interest remains strong.

‚ÄúWhether she runs or not, it‚Äôs clear her most committed supporters are ready to suit up and campaign for her as hard as possible were she to run again,‚Äù Kaivan told the Washington Examiner. ‚ÄúThe response to the teaser announcement showed Harris still garners huge excitement from a segment of the base.‚Äù

Longtime California political expert Garry South suggested Harris should sit out the 2028 race to avoid the risk of serious embarrassment if she ran again.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know what she‚Äôs thinking,‚Äù he told the Washington Examiner. ‚ÄúIt is hard for any politician who‚Äôs run for president not to see a potential president staring back at them in the mirror. In Harris‚Äô case, if she is thinking of running again, perhaps she would be wise to listen to the people of her own home state, those who know her best, who are clearly telling her a very emphatic no, even her fellow Democrats.‚Äù
news.summary: Former Vice President Kamala Harris has reactivated her 2024 campaign social media accounts in a fresh effort to reach younger voters ahead of the midterm elections. Every move Harris makes inevitably draws scrutiny that she will mount a second White House bid in 2028. Experts told the Washington Examiner that this signals that Harris is interested and […]
news.author: Barnini Chakraborty

news.title: I Signed Up for Threads, and Wow, Leftists Are Even Crazier Than I Thought
news.text:
Among these, Threads and Bluesky are the most prominent, and so the other day I decided to get a glimpse into the leftist mindset, and signed up for Threads. And as the kids today say, Wow. Just wow. 

There is all manner of craziness on Threads, including a heavy infestation of men who think they‚Äôre women. One of the most spectacularly insane preoccupations of the platform in general, however, is that the 2024 election was stolen, and Kamala Harris was actually elected president of the United States.

No, I am not making this up. When Harris was touting her big announcement that turned out to be the establishment of Headquarters, ‚Äúthe new Gen-Z led progressive content hub,‚Äù some Threads users were beside themselves with excitement that Harris was going to announce that she had actually won the 2024 election, and, apparently with a simple wave of her hand, rid the world once and for all of Orange Man Bad.

One Threads user wrote: ‚ÄúJust putting it out there... Today @kamalaharris announces that the ‚Äògrave national security threat‚Äô Gabbard has been holding back is irrefutable evidence that Elon Musk was involved in a conspiracy to rig the 2024 election. S**tler is illegitimate and now the country is going to peacefully transfer power to Kamala and Tim Walz. Musk, Miller and S**tler are carted off in handcuffs. A national holiday is proclaimed and no one has to work. I HOPE & WISH.‚Äù 

This is not just the fantasy of one person. On a post about a Daily Beast report saying that ‚ÄúPresident Donald Trump said he will only accept the GOP losing control of Congress in this November‚Äôs midterms if he considers the elections to have been ‚Äòhonest,‚Äô‚Äù another Threads user asked: ‚ÄúLike the 2024 election that he stole from Kamala?‚Äù

This was the time to start backing toward the door, smiling reassuringly, but I plowed on, finding that another big preoccupation at Threads is Trump‚Äôs supposed incapacity. This one is pure projection after four years of Old Joe Biden, during which leftists were insisting against all evidence that the alleged president was sharp as a tack, but Threads users go at it with gusto. One wrote: ‚ÄúTom Llamas NBC News has interviewed President Trump. Trump continues to defend his mental and physical health, but he has all the signs and symptoms of frontal temporal dementia. He is in denial!‚Äù Well, yeah, someone certainly is.

Another provided the prevailing view on Threads of President Donald Trump in a handy and succinct summary post: ‚ÄúTrump is a narcissist, a multiple felon, and a proven sex offender. When the full Epstein Files are released, and not politically redacted, it's likely they will show him to be a pedophile as well. You can't blame a sick old man for this, but he's also incontinent and suffering from dementia.‚Äù

Gavin and Vogue Mag, Sittin‚Äô in a Tree, K-I-S-S-I-N-G‚Ä¶

The Epstein Files are a constant Threads preoccupation, with Threads users absolutely certain that they establish Trump as a monster of world-historical proportions, right up there with the Hitler they insist he is emulating, and that the only reason why he isn‚Äôt in prison right now is because he has bought off essentially most of the world, while his sycophants in the media cover for him. Yes, they really think that the establishment media covers for Trump.

In the final analysis, Threads world, as you may expect, is an ugly, angry world, full of bitter people whose fantasies don‚Äôt match the way the world really is, and who are enraged at the world for failing to rearrange itself to suit them. It would be amusing ‚Äî okay, it frequently is ‚Äî until one remembers that these unhinged people occupy positions of power and influence all over the country today. They‚Äôre even teaching our children. If you ever want to see exactly why that is such a dangerous fact, take a little dip into Threads.
news.author: Robert Spencer

news.title: Dems Have A 'Huge Advantage' In Midterms Following Texas GOP Loss, CNN's Harry Enten Says
news.text:
CNN‚Äôs chief data analyst Harry Enten on Wednesday predicted that a ‚Äúhuge Democratic rebound‚Äù could be on the horizon in this year‚Äôs midterms after the party‚Äôs stunning win in a Texas special election. (Watch his analysis below.)

Enten highlighted polling showing Democrats with a ‚Äúhuge advantage‚Äù over Republicans in New York in 2026 House races (by a margin of +27 points), more than doubling Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äô margin of victory in the state (+13 points).

Enten said GOP representatives in the state like Rep. Mike Lawler (R-N.Y.), who is up for reelection in November, ought to be ‚Äúreally worried‚Äù about the possibility of a blue wave.

‚ÄúAnd oftentimes, Democratic majorities are built on states like New York, eliminating the few Republicans that actually represent it in the House,‚Äù he added.

Enten turned to California, where Democrats are polling at +28 points over Republicans in 2026 House races, a jump from Harris‚Äô margin of victory in her home state back in 2024 (+20 points).

‚ÄúThis is the type of number, if you‚Äôre Democrats, you‚Äôre giving two thumbs up for because this looks like the type of number you want if you want a Democratic majority in the House,‚Äù said the CNN data chief of the party‚Äôs edge in the polls.

On Saturday, Democrat Taylor Rehmet flipped a long-held GOP Texas state Senate seat, beating Donald Trump-backed Republican Leigh Wambsganss in a special election run-off in a district that the president took in the 2024 election.

Sean Spicer, who served as White House press secretary in Trump‚Äôs first term, said lawmakers in the state have expressed their concerns to him over Rehmet‚Äôs victory and claimed one official told him that the seat flip was an ‚Äú8.5 on the Richter scale.‚Äù

Enten referred to Texas Republicans‚Äô push to ‚Äúsqueeze out‚Äù more seats in their favor via their redistricting efforts.

He stressed that Republicans in the state now hold a slim polling advantage over Democrats (by a margin of +2 points) leading up to the midterms, a notable drop from Trump‚Äôs margin of victory in the state back in 2024 (+14 points).

‚ÄúThis looks a whole heck of a lot like what we saw in 2018 when Republicans barely won that House vote,‚Äù Enten said.

Later in the segment, he flagged the strengthening chances of a Democratic ‚Äúblowout‚Äù in November, noting that Kalshi prediction market odds of the GOP taking under 193 House seats have jumped from 8% to 26% in the past three months.

"[A] 26% chance, not just that Democrats win back the House but that Republicans really fall through the floor,‚Äù he concluded.
news.author: Ben Blanchet
